{"abstract": "The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau seeks to limit payday lenders. | The prime minister of Greece says he will carry out his campaign to roll back austerity. | Hidden cash is flowing into high-end real estate. | Shares of HSBC fall on tax avoidance claims.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/02/09/morning-agenda-u-s-takes-on-payday-lenders/", "snippet": "The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau seeks to limit payday lenders. | The prime minister of Greece says he will carry out his campaign to roll back austerity. | Hidden cash is flowing into high-end real estate. | Shares of HSBC fall on tax avo...", "lead_paragraph": " U.S. TAKES ON PAYDAY LENDERS | The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will soon release the first draft of federal regulations to govern a wide range of short-term loans made by the $46 billion payday loan industry, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. The rules are expected to address expensive credit backed by car titles and some installment loans that stretch longer than the traditional two-week payday loan, according to industry lawyers, consumer groups and government authorities briefed on the discussions.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: U.S. Takes On Payday Lenders", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2015-02-09T12:08:45+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/17eea246-7774-5a71-8e88-84a5bf03532e", "word_count": 1986, "uri": "nyt://article/17eea246-7774-5a71-8e88-84a5bf03532e"}

{"abstract": "This week\u2019s business news will include Apple\u2019s conference for software developers, G.M.\u2019s annual meeting with investors, and the European Parliament\u2019s vote on the plans for a landmark trade deal.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/08/business/apples-conference-gms-annual-meeting-and-a-trade-vote-in-europe.html", "snippet": "This week\u2019s business news will include Apple\u2019s conference for software developers, G.M.\u2019s annual meeting with investors, and the European Parliament\u2019s vote on the plans for a landmark trade deal.", "lead_paragraph": "Apple is set to kick off its annual conference for software developers on Monday. The company is expected to show new and improved versions of OS X, its Mac operating system, and iOS, the mobile software system powering iPhones and iPads. The company will also introduce a new streaming music service that it developed with Beats Electronics, the company it acquired last year for $3 billion. Absent from the unveilings will be a long-anticipated upgrade for the Apple TV set-top box, which was pulled from the conference because of issues related to content and technology. \u2014Brian X. {"abstract": "Criminals are always seeking ways to hide their profits, and recent cases highlight the difficulty of keeping up with their latest tactics.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/business/dealbook/the-challenges-of-fighting-money-laundering.html", "snippet": "Criminals are always seeking ways to hide their profits, and recent cases highlight the difficulty of keeping up with their latest tactics.", "lead_paragraph": "The Watergate credo to \u201cfollow the money\u201d is the reason for a number of laws that require banks, credit unions and money-transmission businesses to keep track of who their customers are and report suspicious transactions. {"abstract": "Financial regulators are throwing a bone to sprawling global banks by watering down plans for what happens if a lender goes bust. But it makes resolving crises a bit harder.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/business/dealbook/change-to-bank-rules-could-spur-political-fight-in-a-crisis.html", "snippet": "Financial regulators are throwing a bone to sprawling global banks by watering down plans for what happens if a lender goes bust. But it makes resolving crises a bit harder.", "lead_paragraph": "Global bank supervisors are tying themselves in knots over T.L.A.C. This ugly initialism \u2013 for total loss-absorbing capacity \u2013 is supposed to mean that regulators ensure creditors pay for cross-border bank busts. The emerging rules look likely to be watered down for banks like HSBC, to make sure they aren\u2019t disadvantaged against their less sprawling rivals. But what\u2019s being proposed will make the final system even more prone to political standoffs.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Change to Bank Rules Could Spur Political Fight in a Crisis", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Regulation and Deregulation of Industry", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "HSBC Holdings PLC.", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Financial Stability Board", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-09-10T16:37:23+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By George Hay", "person": [{"firstname": "George", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hay", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a3ccd73e-65df-5a1f-b5e3-3c1881a1e5b3", "word_count": 350, "uri": "nyt://article/a3ccd73e-65df-5a1f-b5e3-3c1881a1e5b3"}

{"abstract": "The lender\u2019s executives have made it clear that they think these worries are more imagined than real, but investors fear the worst is yet to come.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/23/business/dealbook/while-hsbc-stays-upbeat-investors-worry-about-rates-and-china.html", "snippet": "The lender\u2019s executives have made it clear that they think these worries are more imagined than real, but investors fear the worst is yet to come.", "lead_paragraph": "HSBC shares are being weighed down by fear of the future. The global lender thinks it can bolster returns even as its balance sheet shrinks. That is why it increased the dividend despite a 7 percent drop in underlying pretax profit in 2015. But investors remain more worried about negative interest rates, China\u2019s slowdown and cheap oil.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "While HSBC Stays Upbeat, Investors Worry About Rates and China", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "HSBC Holdings PLC.", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Stocks and Bonds", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-02-22T17:45:47+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Peter Thal Larsen", "person": [{"firstname": "Peter", "middlename": "Thal", "lastname": "Larsen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/92297427-385d-5a57-acaf-0c2a2dc74cc0", "word_count": 356, "uri": "nyt://article/92297427-385d-5a57-acaf-0c2a2dc74cc0"}

{"abstract": "On Wednesday, federal prosecutors charged two HSBC employees with \u2018front-running.\u2019 But how do traders use this practice to maximize profits?", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/21/business/dealbook/how-traders-use-front-running-to-profit-from-client-orders.html", "snippet": "On Wednesday, federal prosecutors charged two HSBC employees with \u2018front-running.\u2019 But how do traders use this practice to maximize profits?", "lead_paragraph": "About $5.3 trillion changes hands daily in the foreign exchange market. When banks make trades in currencies on behalf of customers, similar to when they trade other securities like stocks or bonds, they are supposed to put the client\u2019s interests ahead of their own. But that\u2019s not how it always works out. In a case announced on Wednesday, prosecutors say two HSBC employees used information they had gotten about a pending client transaction to trade ahead of it, turning a profit for the bank in the process.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "How Traders Use Front-Running to Profit From Client Orders", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "HSBC Holdings PLC.", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Financial Brokers", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Currency", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-07-20T23:09:30+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Liz Moyer", "person": [{"firstname": "Liz", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Moyer", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/011815d5-3827-5c58-87e4-6910f73324d9", "word_count": 462, "uri": "nyt://article/011815d5-3827-5c58-87e4-6910f73324d9"}
